metadata.title: Temperature-dependence of Zn deposition/stripping behavior in aqueous Zn-based flow batteries

Graphical abstract Low temperatures induce Zn parallel growth along the substrate while high temperatures promote vertical growth. At high temperatures, the preferential Zn deposition at the electrode/membrane interface is the main reason for shortened lifespan of ZFBs. A thorough understanding of the growth behaviors of Zn anode at various temperatures is essential for improving the lifespan of Zn-based flow batteries (ZFBs). However, the impact of temperature on Zn deposition in ZFBs has not been thoroughly investigated. In this work, we find that at low temperatures (0–40 °C) Zn deposit presents a dense and smooth morphology with minimal side reactions, such as hydrogen evolution and aqueous corrosion. Above 60 °C, Zn begins to grow vertically on the substrate, forming larger particles and intensifying side reactions. These differences in Zn growth behaviors at varying temperatures are closely linked to changes in Zn nucleation, as observed through in situ atomic force microscopy. Consequently, elevated temperature in a ZFB promotes preferentially vertical deposition of Zn at the membrane/electrode interface, extending into the membrane. As a result, this significantly hinders ion transport across the membrane and substantially increases the risk of short-circuiting. This process is the primary factor contributing to the reduced lifespan of ZFBs at high temperatures. Keywords Zn-based flow batteries Zn anode Zn deposition In situ characterization 1 Introduction Aqueous Zn-based flow batteries (ZFBs) have become a promising static energy storage technique due to their high energy density, low cost, and environmentally friendly characteristics [1,2]. Technologies such as Zn-bromine flow batteries have already entered the commercial demonstration phase and are expected to play a significant role in distributed energy storage [3,4]. However, the issue of uneven Zn deposition leads to dendrite formation which could cause short-circuiting and thereby shorten the battery’s lifespan [5]. In addition, uneven Zn deposition may also cause the detachment of Zn from the electrode surface, causing capacity loss. Even worse, the detached Zn may further block flow channels, ultimately resulting in battery failure. Moreover, dendrite formation increases the specific surface area, intensifying aqueous corrosion and hydrogen evolution side reaction, which significantly reduces the battery's Coulombic efficiency (CE) and lifetime [6–8]. To address the challenges posed by uneven Zn deposition, researchers have explored various strategies to regulate Zn deposition behavior and extend the battery lifespan. Wu et al. developed a membrane featuring wave-like “Turing patterns,” where the crests and troughs effectively regulate the distribution of Zn(OH)4 2− and expand the space for Zn deposition [9]. Electrode design [10–12] and electrolyte optimization [13,14] are widely used to improve the uniformity and stability of Zn deposition. Several factors influencing Zn deposition are considered in the optimization strategies, such as deposition space, charge distribution, and interfacial states. From a kinetic perspective, Zn deposition is primarily influenced by electrochemical polarization and concentration polarization, both of which are closely related to temperature. Temperature affects these processes by altering reaction rates and ion diffusion [15], making the temperature effects on Zn deposition particularly pronounced under extreme conditions. Researchers have made a significant effort to expand the operating temperature windows of Zn-ion batteries. Key strategies including developing high-concentration salt electrolytes [16,17], organic co-solvent systems [14,18], and deep eutectic electrolytes [19] were employed to regulate the solvation structure of Zn2+ and the morphology of deposited Zn. In addition, methods such as constructing hydrogel networks [20], adding polymer additives [21], and using solid or quasi-solid electrolytes [22,23] have been widely applied to slow down the growth of Zn dendrites. These techniques have significantly enhanced the performance of Zn-ion batteries over a wider temperature range [24]. However, these solutions are no longer suitable for ZFBs. The high viscosity of concentrated salts and deep eutectic electrolytes hamper electrolyte flow and restrict mass transfer, while organic co-solvent electrolytes present significant safety and cost concerns in flow battery applications. Additionally, gel and quasi-solid electrolytes are unsuitable for flow batteries due to their limited areal capacity. Furthermore, there is limited research to expand the operating temperature windows of ZFBs. In addition, the fundamental mechanisms of Zn deposition under extreme temperature conditions remain insufficiently explored. Su et al. have studied the Temperature-dependent nucleation and growth behaviors in Zn-ion batteries [25]. However, these studies are primarily based on Zn foil electrodes with very low areal capacity (∼1 mA h cm−2), whereas flow batteries typically feature much higher areal capacity (>20 mA h cm−2) and often utilize three-dimensional (3D) electrodes like carbon felts. Temperature effects on Zn deposition have not been documented for flow battery systems under high areal capacities. In this study, we systematically investigated the temperature effects on Zn deposition and battery lifespan for aqueous ZFBs. ZnBr2 was chosen as the electrolyte primarily due to its high solubility, low cost, and the representative nature of zinc-bromine flow batteries (ZBFBs). The optimal operating temperature range for ZBFB is 0–60 °C [3,26], which is also the focus of the temperature range in this study. Our results show that under the same areal capacity, the morphology of Zn deposits remains similar at temperatures ranging from 0 to 40 °C. Above 60 °C, the morphology changes significantly, leading to a much shorter battery lifespan. This is because high temperature accelerates the vertical growth of Zn, causing penetration of the membrane, which hinders ion transport and leads to polarization or even short circuits. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Zinc bromide (Israel Chemicals), potassium chloride (Liaoning Quan Rui Reagent Co., Ltd., China), carbon felt (Liaoyang J-Carbon Materials Co., Ltd., China) and graphite plate electrodes (Jiangsu Shenzhou carbon product Co., Ltd.) were used as received. The membrane (900 µm Daramic® HP Polypore (Shanghai)) was purchased from Membrane Products Co., Ltd., China. All electrolytes were prepared with deionized water. 2.2 Characterization The morphologies of Zn deposition were characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JSM-7900F). Energy-dispersive X-ray spectra (EDS) were recorded using an Oxford EDS IE250 system. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of deposits were acquired using an X-ray diffractometer (D8 ADVANCE ECO, λ = 1.54056 Å; RIGAKU, Japan). Laser confocal scanning microscopy (LCSM, VK-8550) was used to investigate surface fluctuation. The height data of the target sample was obtained via the height screen (HT SCRN) mode, which synthesized the lens position data of each pixel into a 256-level grayscale. Moreover, 3D images could be obtained in solid mode, in which the surfaces were filled with different colors based on height data. The samples used in the above characterizations were all obtained after plating 15 or 60 min under the current density of 20 mA cm−2 in different temperatures. 2.3 CF||Zn symmetric flow cell assembly and tests The CF||Zn symmetric flow cell employed a 5 mm-thick carbon felt (CF) as the negative electrode and a 4.35 mm-thick carbon felt with 0.5 mm Zn foil as the positive electrode. The electrode effective area was 48 cm2 (6 cm × 8 cm). The positive and negative electrolytes flow through their electrode cavities respectively and return to the same reservoir (150 mL, 1 M ZnBr2 + 2 M KCl). The flow rate of the electrolyte was 50–60 mL min−1. Batteries were tested by ARBIN (LBT, America) and NEWARE (CT-4008 T-5V12A) charge–discharge testing systems. Specifically, all the batteries were tested in the constant temperature chamber (ET-020L-Shanghai Espec) and rested for 2 h with a running pump before tests. The cell testing procedure was conducted as follows: Each cycle comprised four consecutive steps. (1) Constant-current charging at 0.96 A (equivalent to 20 mA cm−2) until either reaching 1-h duration or exceeding 0.4 V terminal voltage (whichever occurred first). (2) An open-circuit rest period of 20 s. (3) Constant-current discharging at −0.96 A until the voltage dropped below −0.4 V. (4) Another 20 s open-circuit interval. This sequence was repeated continuously to evaluate the electrochemical cycling performance. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements A typical three-electrode system was used for the cyclic voltammetry (CV) and chronoamperometry tests on an electrochemical workstation (CHI660E) and VMP3 (Biologic Science Instrument) with 100 mL electrolyte (0.6 M ZnBr2 + 2 M KCl). A glassy carbon electrode (diameter, 6 mm) was used as the working electrode, Zn plate with an area of 9 cm2 (3 cm × 3 cm) was used as the counter electrode. A saturated calomel electrode (SCE, Tianjin Gaoshiruilian Co., Ltd.) was used as the reference electrode. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and crystal structure characterization of Zn deposition To investigate the electrochemical deposition behavior of Zn2+, we first studied the morphology of Zn deposits at different temperatures via FESEM. Fig. 1 a–h and Fig. S1 clearly show the morphological changes of Zn deposits on the graphite surface at a current density of 20 mA cm−2 and an areal capacity of 20 mA h cm−2. As shown in Fig. S1a–c, Zn deposits grow in a dot-like pattern at 0–40 °C. When the temperature increases to 60 °C, the deposits exhibit a peanut-shaped morphology (Fig. S1d). Higher magnification images (Fig. 1a–d) reveal that low-temperature deposits merge into dense layers with multi-directional growth. As the temperature increases, the size of Zn particles gradually increases, and the voids between the particles become larger. It is noteworthy that Fig. 1e–h shows magnified images of the Zn deposits in Fig. 1a–d. Within the temperature range of 0–40 °C, the Zn deposits exhibit a smooth and uniform surface (Fig. 1e–g). However, at 60 °C large pores appear on the surface (Fig. 1h). The small holes observed in Fig. 1e may be caused by gas bubbles generated by hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) during charging, which physically hinder Zn deposition. In contrast, the large pores covering the entire electrode surface in Fig. 1h may be related to the Zn deposition morphology, with these pores formed by vertically oriented Zn flakes, creating a honeycomb-like structure. 3D cross-sectional images obtained by LCSM show that the surface height differences of the Zn deposits increase from 34.95 µm at 0 °C to 59.76 µm at 60 °C (Fig. 1i–l and Fig. S2). These results suggest that temperature significantly affects the morphology of Zn deposits. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) tests confirmed that the surface area at higher temperatures is significantly larger than that at lower temperatures (Fig. 1m and Fig. S3), which could aggravate side reactions related to aqueous corrosion. To further study the intrinsic properties of the Zn deposition at different temperatures, XRD patterns of Zn deposits at various temperatures were collected (Fig. 1n). The intensity of all peaks is normalized with respect to the (102) plane. As the deposition temperature increases, the intensity of (002) diffraction peak decreases, while the signal from the (101) plane increases. As we know, the (002) plane is nearly parallel to the substrate, while the (101) plane tends to grow at an angle range of 30° to 70° to the substrate, often leading to irregular particle morphology [27]. This suggests that high temperatures promote the formation of Zn dendrites. Our previous studies calculated the surface energies of different planes and found that the (002) plane has the lowest surface energy, making it the dominant plane in Zn deposition [28]. This also explains the Temperature-dependent evolution of the dominant crystal plane in Zn deposition. As the temperature increases, other planes have more chance to participate in deposition, resulting in a weakened (002) peak intensity. The diffraction peaks at 70° (assigned to the (103) and (110) planes) show reduced intensity with increasing temperature. This trend can be attributed to the high surface energy of (103) and (110) planes [28], since elevated temperatures thermodynamically favor low-surface-energy morphologies while low temperatures kinetically stabilize high-surface-energy planes. 3.2 Deposition mechanism analysis To elucidate the mechanisms behind the above morphological changes and variations of the dominant crystal planes during Zn deposition, we investigated the nucleation behavior during Zn deposition at different temperatures. Fig. S4a shows the current–time curves measured by chronoamperometry (test time: 15 s; potential: −1.20 V versus saturated calomel electrode (SCE)) at different temperatures. Each curve exhibits a distinct peak current, typical of a 3D nucleation process controlled by hemispherical diffusion. In the initial stage, the current increases as the expanded electroactive area is associated with nucleation until it reaches the peak. Subsequently, the current decreases and stabilizes, indicating that the process is diffusion-controlled [29]. Additionally, as the temperature increases the peak current rises, and the time to reach the peak decreases (Fig. S4b), indicating that higher temperatures accelerate the kinetics of Zn deposition. The time to reach the peak current and the stable current value after 15 s at 60 °C are similar to those at 70 °C, indicating that the temperature has a negligible effect on the reaction rate above 60 °C. Moreover, the same trend was also observed in cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements (Fig. S5), consistent with the morphological changes when the temperature exceeds 60 °C. CV curves at different scan rates and temperatures are shown in Fig. S6. The reduction peak increases linearly with the square root of the scan rate (Fig. 2 a), indicating that the Zn deposition is diffusion-controlled [30]. In this case, the nucleation process can be studied using diffusion-controlled growth theory [31]. This theory classifies nucleation into two types: instantaneous and progressive, which can be expressed by the following equation [32]. Instantaneous ( j / j m ) 2 = 1.9542 ( t / t m ) - 1 1 − exp − 1.2564 t / t m 2 Progressive ( j / j m ) 2 = 1.2254 ( t / t m ) - 1 1 − exp − 2.3367 t / t m 2 2 where j m and t m represent the maximum current and the corresponding time, respectively. Fig. 2b shows the relationship between ( j / j m ) 2 and t / t m at different temperatures. It can be observed that in the initial stage ( t / t m < 1), the curves at all temperatures match the instantaneous nucleation model well. When t / t m exceeds 1, the curves deviate from the theoretical model. Even after adjusting the voltage and the area of the working electrode, the experimental results remained consistent (Fig. S8). This deviation has been attributed to the assumption in the theoretical model that the electrode surface is smooth and defect-free. However, the surface of the deposited Zn typically contains defects such as dislocations and scratches, which serve as additional active sites for metal ion nucleation during deposition. As a result, the actual deposition current is often higher than the theoretical prediction [33,34]. Instantaneous nucleation assumes that all nuclei form simultaneously at all available growth sites and grow at the same rate. Therefore, the size and number of initial nuclei determine the morphology of the subsequent Zn growth [28]. Fig. 2c presents the CV curves of the Zn2+/Zn redox couple at different temperatures. It can be seen that the potential gap between the starting reduction potential (A’/B’) and the crossover point (A/B) is regarded as the nucleation overpotential (ƞ) [35]. The relationship between the critical radius of Zn nuclei (r) and the nucleation overpotential can be expressed by the following equation [36,37]. r = 2 γ V m F ∣ ƞ ∣ In this equation, γ, V m , and F represent the surface energy of the Zn-electrolyte interface, the molar volume of crystal Zn and Faraday’s constant, respectively. Fig. 2c shows that the nucleation overpotential (ƞ, 4.3 mV) at 60 °C is significantly lower than that at 25 °C (ƞ, 24.0 mV), indicating that higher temperatures favor the formation of larger Zn nuclei. To further understand the above nucleation results and better illustrate the Zn growth process, in situ atomic force microscopy (AFM) was used to observe the morphology of Zn deposits during the early plating stage. As shown in Fig. 2d, during the first 15 s of nucleation at 25 °C numerous small Zn particles were formed. The adjacent Zn nuclei gradually grow and merge together during the subsequent deposition (60–120 s), with their height stabilizing around 430–530 nm over time. At 60 °C, the number of Zn nuclei was reduced but their size was larger (Fig. 2e). The change in nucleation number agrees with the electrochemical findings. During the subsequent growth phase, their height increased dramatically, rising from 700 nm to 2.5 µm. These results indicate that high temperatures promote the vertical growth of Zn. Based on the above electrochemical and in situ AFM experimental results, the influence of Zn nucleation and growth mode on morphology can be illustrated in Fig. 3 a, b. At lower temperatures (0–40 °C), the deposition process favors the formation of smaller particles growing parallel to the substrate. In contrast, at higher temperatures the reduced number of nucleation sites results in the formation of larger Zn particles and tends to grow vertically. This process is more clearly illustrated by the Zn deposition morphology under low areal capacity (5 mA h cm−2) at different temperatures in Fig. 3c–j. The growth pattern at lower temperatures tends to form multiple parallel hexagonal structures [38]. In contrast, at 60 °C the Zn deposits exhibit numerous small plate-like structures oriented perpendicular to the substrate, forming honeycomb-like pores that greatly increase the surface area. This observation agrees with the BET results presented earlier in Fig. 1m. 3.3 Symmetric flow cell performance We constructed a symmetric flow cell using Zn foil as the positive electrode and carbon felt (CF) as the negative electrode to evaluate its stability and efficiency across different temperatures (CF||Zn flow cell). The Daramic porous membrane (900 µm thick), commonly used in ZBFBs, is selected as the membrane due to its significantly lower cost, high ion conductivity, and stability. In the test, the cell is first charged, dissolving the Zn foil in the positive electrode and depositing Zn metal onto the carbon felt at the negative electrode. As shown in Fig. S9, the charge and discharge curves from the first cycle indicate that the polarization is gradually weakened with increasing temperature. This improvement in performance is primarily attributed to the accelerated Zn deposition/stripping reaction kinetics at elevated temperatures, where the higher temperature not only enhances the mass transfer rate of Zn2+ (Fig. S7) but also boosts the charge transfer kinetics. However, as the number of cycles increases, the polarization effect at high temperatures intensifies, resulting in a rise in charging voltage and significantly shortening the battery's lifespan (Fig. 4 a–d). Meanwhile, the changes in the battery's Coulombic efficiency (CE) are illustrated in Fig. 4e. At 0 °C, the average CE for the first 30 cycles was 99.40%. As the temperature rises, CE drops rapidly. When the temperature reaches 60 °C, the battery can complete only 3 cycles before its CE drops sharply to 73.37%. The decline in CE can be attributed to several factors: firstly, the HER during charging [39,40]; secondly, the detachment of “dead Zn” particles from the carbon felt electrode; lastly, the formation of ZnO due to aqueous corrosion [41–43]. Fig. S10 presents the EDS images of Zn deposited at different temperatures under an areal capacity of 20 mA h cm−2. As the temperature increases to 60 °C, the EDS mapping images show a gradual decrease in the Zn content, while the O content increases. Fig. 4f illustrates the variation in the mass content of O and Zn based on EDS analysis. Between 0–40 °C, the O content remains relatively stable but a significant increase is observed at 60 °C, which corresponds to the trend in morphological change. When temperatures surpass 60 °C, the expanded specific surface area of the Zn deposits accelerates reactions with water and dissolved O2 in the electrolyte. Moreover, elevated temperatures (>60 °C) intensify the HER, leading to the generation of excess hydroxide ions (OH−) that further facilitate the formation of zinc oxide (ZnO). To study the impact of hydrogen evolution on CE during battery cycling, we constructed a device (Fig. S11) for in situ gas chromatography (GC) to monitor hydrogen evolution at various temperatures. As shown in Fig. 4g, h, the results indicate that the increase in temperature significantly intensifies hydrogen evolution side reactions. At 25 °C, the HER exhibits a clear trend of variation during cycling. In the initial cycle, the hydrogen concentration in the measuring vial reaches 51.9 ppm during the charging process, but it subsequently decreases in the following cycles. This reduction can be attributed to two mechanisms: (1) the residual metallic Zn on the CF surface lowers the overpotential for subsequent Zn deposition, thermodynamically alleviating the hydrogen evolution side reactions; (2) compared to CF, the higher HER overpotential on metallic Zn further suppresses the HER process from a kinetic perspective. At high temperatures (60 °C), the initial H2 concentration rises to 60.7 ppm, primarily due to the intensified electrochemical-hydrogen evolution and aqueous corrosion-induced chemical hydrogen evolution reactions. Additionally, high temperatures promote the vertical growth of Zn on the substrate, causing it to extend into the membrane, which restricts ion transport. This, in turn, exacerbates battery polarization and the HER process, ultimately causing the H2 concentration to exceed 251.2 ppm. Simultaneously, the porous structures formed at elevated temperatures possess a larger specific surface area, increasing contact with water and further aggravating HER [44,45]. Most importantly, Zn deposition may grow into the membrane at high temperatures, (Fig. 5 a, b), hindering ion transfer and leading to increased polarization (Fig. 4c, d) [46]. To validate the results, we investigated ion diffusion behavior across the membrane. As shown in Fig. S12, comparative analysis revealed that the membrane subjected to 20 cycles at 60 °C exhibited dramatically reduced diffusion for Zn2+ than pristine membrane. In addition, we analyzed the membrane after Zn deposition at different temperatures. Under high-temperature conditions, more Zn entered the membrane compared to low-temperature conditions (Fig. 5c–e). During discharge, any residual Zn within the membrane tends to detach from the electrodes, forming electrochemically inactive “dead Zn”. The Zn in the membrane will block the membrane pores and affect the ion transport. This is the main reason for the polarization of the battery. However, when using a dense Nafion115 membrane for cell assembly, the compact surface of the membrane prevents Zn from growing into the membrane (Fig. S13). Therefore, the symmetric flow cell assembled with the Nafion115 membrane can run stably for more than 100 cycles (Fig. S14). Compared to the two-dimensional Zn foil electrode, Zn deposition on the 3D porous carbon felt electrode is not limited to the surface and can also occur within the interior. With the areal capacity of 5 mA h cm−2, along with the temperature increases, Zn deposition at the electrode/membrane interface gradually increases, while deposition at the current collector/electrode interface decreases (Fig. 5f–m). When the areal capacity further increased to 20 mA h cm−2, this phenomenon becomes even more pronounced (Figs. S15 and S16). This behavior further promotes Zn growth into the membrane, leading to the blockage of membrane pores by Zn deposition, which exacerbates polarization. Simulation data (Fig. S17) also confirms that, under high-temperature conditions, the Zn2+ concentration at the membrane/electrode interface is significantly lower than that under low temperature. The result further highlights that Zn deposition tends to occur more readily at the interface between the membrane and electrode at elevated temperatures, increasing the likelihood of Zn penetrating the membrane pores, which in turn causes polarization. In a symmetric cell, during Zn deposition the supporting electrolyte forms an electrical circuit through the membrane (Fig. 5a). The carbon felt surface near the membrane reaches the necessary charge balance for Zn deposition first, resulting in less polarization at that location compared to other areas. Zn deposition occurs in three steps: mass transfer, desolvation, and charge transfer. At low temperatures, all three factors simultaneously determine the deposition rate, allowing Zn2+ to deposit on other areas across the carbon felt. As the temperature increases to 60 °C, the mass transfer rate improves, more Zn2+ undergoes desolvation, so charge balance becomes the limiting factor. Consequently, Zn deposition becomes more pronounced on the membrane side than on other areas at higher temperatures. Therefore, inhibiting the growth of Zn into the membrane can significantly enhance the temperature adaptability of ZFBs. By designing a non-conductive buffer layer (such as glass fiber) between the membrane and carbon felt, sufficient space is provided for Zn deposition, preventing Zn growth into the membrane. Additionally, developing dense or high-mechanical-strength membranes can effectively address the issue of Zn growth within the membrane. Considering factors such as morphological differences, side reactions, CE, and cycle life, the operating temperature range for symmetric cells is more reasonable within 0–40 °C. However, taking into account the battery polarization and the reaction kinetics of catholyte, the optimal operating temperature range for ZFBs should be between 25–40 °C. Compared to symmetric cells, full batteries assembled with porous membranes have an oxidized solution on the cathode side, and this oxidized state also fills the pores of the membrane. Zn entering the membrane will be dissolved by the oxidized electrolyte, effectively alleviating the blockage of the ion transport channels. Therefore, conventional ZFBs exhibit a significantly longer cycle life in the 25–40 °C range compared to symmetric cells. However, excessively high temperatures may still lead to the aforementioned issues. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, the optimal operating temperature range for ZFBs should be between 25–40 °C. The main reason for the shortened battery life above 60 °C is the preferential deposition of Zn at the carbon felt/membrane interface and its penetration into the membrane, which hinders ion transport and intensifies polarization. Therefore, improving the temperature adaptability of ZFBs should not only focus on mitigating Zn dendrite growth and side reactions but also place greater emphasis on optimizing the structure of the carbon felt electrode and reducing preferential Zn deposition at the carbon felt/membrane interface. coredata.dc:description: A thorough understanding of the growth behaviors of Zn anode at various temperatures is essential for improving the lifespan of Zn-based flow batteries (ZFBs). However, the impact of temperature on Zn deposition in ZFBs has not been thoroughly investigated. In this work, we find that at low temperatures (0–40 °C) Zn deposit presents a dense and smooth morphology with minimal side reactions, such as hydrogen evolution and aqueous corrosion. Above 60 °C, Zn begins to grow vertically on the substrate, forming larger particles and intensifying side reactions. These differences in Zn growth behaviors at varying temperatures are closely linked to changes in Zn nucleation, as observed through in situ atomic force microscopy. Consequently, elevated temperature in a ZFB promotes preferentially vertical deposition of Zn at the membrane/electrode interface, extending into the membrane. As a result, this significantly hinders ion transport across the membrane and substantially increases the risk of short-circuiting. This process is the primary factor contributing to the reduced lifespan of ZFBs at high temperatures.

coredata.dc:title: Temperature-dependence of Zn deposition/stripping behavior in aqueous Zn-based flow batteries
